name: Electrical Burning Smell Investigation
description: A burning smell from electrical sources is a serious warning sign. Something is overheating—and overheating leads to fire. Solomon Electric provides emergency investigation of electrical burning smells throughout South Florida. We find the source, assess the danger, and fix the problem before it becomes a fire.
warningSignsSubheading: Different smells indicate different problems—all require investigation.

problems.title: Burning Plastic Smell
problems.description: Wire insulation is degrading from overheating. This often precedes electrical fires. Find the source immediately.

problems.title: Fish or Urine Smell
problems.description: Overheating plastic components produce this distinctive odor. Despite the strange description, electrical problems often smell this way.

problems.title: Smell at Outlet or Switch
problems.description: Localized burning smell indicates overheating at that specific device—loose connections or overloaded circuit.

problems.title: Smell from Electrical Panel
problems.description: Burning smell at the panel is an emergency. Overheating in the panel can escalate to fire rapidly. Don't delay investigation.

problems.title: Intermittent Smell
problems.description: Smells that come and go may indicate problems only under load. We investigate under various conditions to find the source.

problems.title: Smell with Flickering Lights
problems.description: Combination of burning smell and flickering suggests loose connections causing both arcing heat and intermittent contact.

process.title: Immediate Assessment
process.description: We determine the urgency level. Active burning or visible smoke requires immediate power shutoff. We assess safety before proceeding.

process.title: Source Location
process.description: Using physical inspection and thermal imaging, we locate the source of overheating—panel, outlet, junction box, or appliance.

process.title: Root Cause Analysis
process.description: We determine WHY overheating is occurring: loose connections, overloaded circuits, failed components, or damaged wiring.

process.title: Damage Assessment
process.description: We evaluate whether the overheating has damaged wiring, components, or surrounding materials requiring additional repair.

process.title: Repair and Verification
process.description: We repair the underlying problem, replace damaged components, and verify the issue is resolved before restoring power.

benefits.title: Fire Prevention
benefits.description: Burning smells indicate overheating that can ignite fires. Finding and fixing the source prevents what could become catastrophic damage.

benefits.title: Find Hidden Problems
benefits.description: Burning smell may indicate larger issues—failing panel, degraded wiring, overloaded circuits. Investigation reveals the complete picture.

benefits.title: Peace of Mind

benefits.title: Documentation

faqs.question: Is electrical burning smell an emergency?
faqs.answer: Yes—treat it as an emergency. Burning smell means overheating is occurring, which can progress to fire. Turn off power if you can identify the source (breaker for that area), and call for investigation. Don't wait until morning or Monday.

faqs.question: What does electrical burning smell like?
faqs.answer: Often like burning plastic—acrid and chemical. Sometimes described as 'fishy' or like urine (burning electrical components produce this odd smell). Any unusual burning odor near electrical equipment warrants investigation.

faqs.question: Should I turn off power if I smell burning?
faqs.answer: If you can identify where the smell is coming from, turn off the breaker for that circuit. If the smell is from the panel or you can't locate the source, turn off the main breaker. Don't restore power until the problem is found and fixed.

faqs.question: What causes electrical overheating?
faqs.answer: Common causes: loose connections (most common), overloaded circuits, failing components, damaged wiring, improper installations. All create resistance that converts electricity to heat—potentially enough to ignite fires.

faqs.question: What if the smell is intermittent?
faqs.answer: Intermittent smell may only occur under load. We investigate under various conditions—lights on, HVAC running, high-use times—to find problems that only appear during specific circumstances.

faqs.question: Could it be something other than electrical?
faqs.answer: Possibly. HVAC systems, appliances, and other sources can produce burning smells. We help determine whether the source is electrical or point you to appropriate help if it's not.

faqs.question: What is thermal imaging inspection?
faqs.answer: Thermal cameras detect heat that's invisible to the eye. Overheating electrical connections show as hot spots. This technology helps us find problems inside walls, panels, and equipment without opening everything up.

faqs.question: What if you find fire damage?
faqs.answer: If we find fire damage—charred wiring, melted components—we document it for insurance, determine extent of damage, and recommend appropriate repairs. Significant hidden fire damage may require insurance claim and major repair work.
